revisions.*: Because "rvslots" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used.

{{Taxobox | image = 2011-05-19 Stropharia rugosoannulata Farl. ex Murrill 183478.jpg | image_width = 234px | regnum = [[fungus|Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Strophariaceae]] | genus = ''[[Stropharia]]'' | species = '''''S. rugosoannulata''''' | binomial = ''Stropharia rugosoannulata'' | binomial_authority = [[William Gibson Farlow|Farlow]] ex [[William Alphonso Murrill|Murrill]] (1922) | synonyms_ref = | synonyms = ''Geophila rugosoannulata'' (Farl. ex Murrill) [[Robert Kühner|Kühner]] & [[Romagn.]] (1953)
''Naematoloma rugosoannulatum'' (Farl. ex Murrill) S.Ito (1959)
''Psilocybe rugosoannulata'' (Farl. ex Murrill) [[Noordel.]] (1995) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Stropharia rugosoannulata'' | whichGills = adnate | capShape = convex | capShape2 = flat | hymeniumType = gills | stipeCharacter = ring | ecologicalType = saprotrophic | sporePrintColor = purple | howEdible = choice }} '''''Stropharia rugosoannulata''''', commonly known as the '''wine cap stropharia''', "'''garden giant'''", '''burgundy mushroom''' or '''king stropharia''' (Japanese: ''saketsubatake''), is an [[agaric]] of the family [[Strophariaceae]] found in [[Europe]] and [[North America]], and introduced to [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]]. The mushroom was reported in April 2018 in [[Colombia]], in the city of [[Bogota]]. Unlike many other members of the genus ''[[Stropharia]]'', it is widely regarded as a choice [[edible mushroom|edible]] and is commercially cultivated. The king stropharia can grow to 20 cm high with a reddish-brown convex to flattening cap up to 30 cm across, the size leading to another colloquial name '''godzilla mushroom'''.{{cite book | author = [[Antonio Carluccio|Carluccio A]] | year = 2003 | title = The Complete Mushroom Book | publisher = Quadrille | isbn = 1-84400-040-0}} The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are initially pale, then grey, and finally dark purple-brown in colour. The firm [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is white, as is the tall [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] which bears a wrinkled [[annulus (mycology)|ring]]. This is the origin of the [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] which means "wrinkled-ringed".{{cite book | author = Pacioni G | year = 1981 | title = Simon & Schusters Guide to Mushrooms | publisher = Simon & Schuster | isbn = 0-671-42849-7}} It is found on wood chips across North America in summer and autumn. Described as very tasty by some authors, king stropharia is easily [[fungiculture|cultivated]] on a medium similar to that on which it grows naturally. [[Antonio Carluccio]] recommends sautéeing them in butter or grilling them. In [[Paul Stamets]]' book ''[[Mycelium Running]]'', a study done by Christiane Pischl showed that the king stropharia makes an excellent garden companion to corn. The fungus also has a European history of being grown with corn. A 2006 study, published in the journal ''Applied and Environmental Microbiology'', found the king stropharia to have the ability to attack the [[nematode]] ''[[Panagrellus redivivus]]''; the fungus produces unique spiny cells called [[Acanthocyte (mycology)|acanthocyte]]s which are able to immobilise and digest the nematodes.{{cite journal |author1=Hong Luo |author2=Xuan Li |author3=Guohong Li |author4=Yanbo Pan |author5=Keqin Zhang |last-author-amp=yes |year=2006 |title=Acanthocytes of Stropharia rugosoannulata Function as a Nematode-Attacking Device |journal=Appl. Environ. Microbiol. |volume=72 |issue=4 |doi=10.1128/AEM.72.4.2982-2987.2006 |pages=2982–7 |pmc=1449000 |pmid=16598005}} See [[nematophagous fungus]]. ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web |title=''Stropharia rugosoannulata'' Farl. ex Murrill 1922 |url=http://www.mycobank.org/MycoTaxo.aspx?Link=T&Rec=145219 |publisher=[[MycoBank]]. International Mycological Association |accessdate=2011-09-11}} }} === Cited literature === * {{cite book | author = Phillips, Roger | year = 1991 | title = Mushrooms of North America | publisher = Little, Brown & Co. | isbn = 0-316-70613-2}} * Zadrazil, Frantisek and Joachim Schliemann: "Ein Beitrag zur Ökologie und Anbautechnik von Stropharia rugosoannulata (Farlow ex Murr.)" in: Der Champignon Nr.163, March 1975 {{Taxonbar|from=Q1236980}} [[Category:Strophariaceae]] [[Category:Carnivorous fungi]] [[Category:Edible fungi]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1922]] [[Category:Fungi of New Zealand]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]] [[Category:Fungi in cultivation]] [[Category:Fungal pest control agents]]
